Les photos de la semaine du 27 octobre
02 Nov 2019 by Le Devoir


1. Healdsburg, 27 octobre 2019 | Un populaire domaine viticole de Californie, le Soda Rock Winery, a été la proie des flammes dimanche dernier, près de la ville de Healdsburg. Le « Kincade Fire » qui sévit depuis le 23 octobre au nord de San Francisco a brûlé plus de 31 000 hectares de végétation et détruit plus de 250 bâtiments. Les pompiers étaient parvenus à le maîtriser à 68 % vendredi. D’autres incendies ravagent toujours cet État de la côte-ouest américaine.Josh Edelson Agence France-Presse



2. Nghe An (Vietnam), 27 octobre 2019 | Le Minh Tuan est inconsolable. Ce père d’un jeune homme de 30 ans, Le Van Ha, craint que son fils figure parmi la quarantaine de personnes retrouvées sans vie dans un camion réfrigéré en Grande-Bretagne il y a quelques jours. Vendredi, la police britannique a annoncé que les victimes étaient probablement de nationalité vietnamienne.Nhac Nguyen Agence France-Presse



3. Santiago (Chili), 27 octobre 2019 | Une artiste prend la pose, vêtue d’une jupe à l’effigie du drapeau chilien, les mains couvertes de peinture rouge pour illustrer du sang. Depuis le 18 octobre, un vaste mouvement de contestation sociale secoue le pays, durant lequel 20 personnes ont perdu la vie. Lundi, le président chilien, Sebastian Piñera, a annoncé le remplacement de huit ministres sur 24.Esteban Felix Associated Press Photo



4. Kelowna, 26 octobre 2019 | Le Canadien Nam Nguyen n’a pas boudé son plaisir, samedi dernier, lorsqu’il a remporté la médaille d’argent au Grand Prix de patinage artistique de l’ISU, tenu en Colombie-Britannique.Geoff Robins Agence France-Presse



5. San Andres Itzapa (Guatemala), 28 octobre 2019 | Une fillette de trois ans fume un cigare, lors des célébrations du saint Simon. Des milliers de personnes croient que ce saint les aide à trouver du travail, à résoudre les problèmes familiaux et à guérir les maladies. Chaque année, des fidèles du Guatemala, mais également du Mexique et de pays d’Amérique centrale viennent remercier saint Simon de ses bienfaits ou leur demander sa bénédiction pour migrer vers le nord.Orlando Estrada Agence France-Presse



6. Barcelone, 27 octobre 2019 | Les Catalans qui souhaitent faire partie de l’Espagne ont pris part dimanche à une importante contre-manifestation afin de faire entendre la voix de la « majorité silencieuse ». La Catalogne est plongée dans une crise politique depuis la tentative de sécession de la région en 2017. La semaine dernière, la Cour suprême espagnole a condamné neuf indépendantistes catalans à des peines allant de neuf à 13 ans de prison pour leur rôle dans le référendum avorté.Lluis Gene Agence France-Presse



7. Montréal, 27 octobre 2019 | Coeur de Pirate est repartie à la maison avec deux Félix en main après le Gala de l'ADISQ, dimanche. Son dernier effort, , a gagné le trophée de l’album pop de l’année, et Béatrice Martin a aussi été couronnée interprète féminine de l’année. L’auteure-compositrice et pianiste Alexandra Stréliski a aussi remporté deux statuettes — celles de l’auteure-compositrice de l’année et de la révélation de l’année.Valérian Mazataud Le DevoirEn cas de tempête, ce jardin sera fermé



8. Montréal, 27 octobre 2019 | Pour une première fois, l’ADISQ remettait un trophée pour l’artiste autochtone de l’année. Tandis que plusieurs voyaient Elisapie comme favorite — son disque ayant été finaliste au prix Polaris —, c’est plutôt le patriarche Florent Vollant qui a vu son nom gravé sur cette toute première statuette.Valérian Mazataud Le Devoir



9. Montréal, 31 octobre 2019 | Quelques enfants, souvent accompagnés de leurs parents, ont défié le temps pluvieux et ont passé outre la décision de Montréal et de plusieurs autres villes d’annuler la tournée d’Halloween du 31 octobre : costumés et maquillés comme il se doit, ils ont parcouru les rues de leur quartier jeudi soir, allant de porte en porte solliciter des friandises.Jacques Nadeau Le Devoir



10. Montréal, 1er novembre 2019 | Les vents forts qui ont soufflé à Montréal ont causé d’importants dommages. Quelque 250 arbres ont été abîmés, voire déracinés, selon la Ville. Au plus fort de la tempête, tout près d’un million d’abonnés d’Hydro-Québec n’avaient plus d’électricité. La météo brutale a aussi fait une victime en Montérégie.Marie-France Coallier Le Devoir

Political persecution or tax fraud: Australia v. Chinese tycoon
Real estate developer Huang Xiangmu donated millions to Australia's major parties and rubbed off on top ministers and politicians before he was expelled from the country on suspicion of ties to the government in China. The Australian Tax Authority is now demanding $ 100 million from it and determined to bring it into bankruptcy
02 Nov 2019 by Ofir Dor, Beijing
Last month, a federal court judge upheld the local tax authority's request to freeze all of its property in Chinese real estate tycoon Huang Xiangmo. Huang's main asset is a huge mansion overlooking Sydney Harbor purchased for $ 12.8 million in 2013, two years after the tycoon moved to live in Australia. At the same time, the court requires Huang to provide a complete list of all its assets worldwide.
Huang's entry into Australia was banned last December after his residence permit in the country was revoked and his application for local citizenship was rejected on the recommendation of the Australian intelligence agency. However, that did not end Huang's troubles, which are currently being sued by the Australian tax authorities for a huge debt of $ 141 million (about $ 100 million). Authorities say Huang falsely reported his income in 2013-2015.
Parties ignored the intelligence service warning Huang made his fortune in real estate in China, before moving permanently to Australia in 2011. He founded in Australia an entrepreneurial company called Yuhu that has built large commercial, office and residential projects across the state. At the same time, Huang quickly became a leading political donor for Australia's two largest parties - the Labor Party and the Liberal Party. Overall, Huang donated $ 2.7 million to Australian political parties. The big donations helped Huang establish personal relationships with the country's top leaders. In a long line of photos, he is photographed smiling alongside former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, Labor Party leader and opposition leader Bill Shorten and then Foreign Minister Julie Bishop. As early as 2015, Australian intelligence secretary-general head Duncan Lois secretly warned parties receiving donations from Huang, which is suspected of being close to the Chinese Communist Party. Due to Huang's role as chairman of the China Peace Promotion Council, the Australian intelligence agency said Beijing was a tool to promote Beijing's influence abroad. But the warning from the bion did not really affect the parties, who continued to receive hundreds of thousands of dollars more from Huang in the years to come.


Huang Xiangmu Photo: AP

Things began to change only in 2017, when the relationship between Huang and Labor Senator Sam Destiari exploded. Huang paid Senator Dustiari's private legal accounts and according to Dustiari publications in exchange for inquiries about the status of Huang's citizenship application and informed him that his phones were being monitored. Destiari even appeared alongside Huang at a Chinese-language press conference in which he expressed support for China's position on the territorial dispute in the South China Sea in contrast to his party's position. Following the explosion of the affair, Destiari was forced to resign. The affair has led to a significant shift in Australian leadership, which has become more suspicious of what has been defined as the covert intervention of foreign governments, especially the Chinese government, in the local political system. In late 2017, the Australian government approved a series of anti-foreign intervention laws, including a total ban on foreign donations by political parties, a move that increased tensions in the Beijing-Canberra axis when China accused Australia of paranoia. Last December, Australian authorities seized an opportunity where Huang exited the state and quickly revoked his residency visa, effectively deporting him from the state. The official claim was that doubts were raised about the honesty of his answers in the citizenship process. Huang settled in Hong Kong. A few months later, the Australian tax authorities also came in with demands. Tax authorities say that in recent months, after learning about the investigation against him, Huang spent about $ 50 million from Australia. The tax authority also claims that Huang deliberately created complex business structures to make it more difficult to collect debt. In court, a tax representative declared that her goal was to get Huang declared bankruptcy, a situation that would help take over his assets and collect the huge debt. At the same time as the Tax Authority, last month the Independent Anti-Corruption Commission in Australia began an investigation into the case that Huang allegedly made to the New South Wales State Labor Party a $ 100,000 domestic donation. The donation was allegedly made in cash in a plastic bag and was illegal as New South Wales bans real estate developers from making political donations. During the investigation, Huang also revealed that $ 35,000 was donated to the Labor Party In the state, to cover his legal expenses in his fight against sexual harassment charges. He asked the parties to reimburse him for his contributions over the years to all the charges against him, which he called "baseless". Huang explained that he had moved to Australia because of "the beautiful scenery and simple customs" and claimed that even after years of investigations, the Australian intelligence services did not find a stub of evidence that he had spied or served as an influence agent of the Chinese Communist Party. He claims he donated funds to the parties to promote the involvement of Chinese citizens in Australia in local politics. After his stay in China was revoked, Huang remained indebted and demanded that the political parties give him back the donations if they were unworthy so that he could donate the money instead of to charities. Needless to say, donations have never been returned. He claims he never donated money of his own accord, but at the request of the parties themselves. In an interview with the nationalist Chinese newspaper Global Times, Huang claimed that Australia was acting like an "overgrown baby". "Growing babies is taking time and Australia has a long way to go," said Huang. “This should not be the way a system that claims to be democratic and operates under the rule of law is exploiting its power. If you act like that in China today, you will do so tomorrow for Arabs and Jews, which is a dangerous thing. " In a statement issued to the Guardian this week, Huang called the tax authorities' lawsuit against him "a contemptible tool for political persecution" and claimed to have been persecuted by "unknown opal forces."
